name: care
content:
care noun
(PROTECTION)
Add to word list
Add to word list
B2 [ U ] the process of protecting someone or something and providing what that person or thing needs: The standard of care at our local hospital is excellent. Mira's going to be very weak for a long time after the operation, so she'll need a lot of care. Nurseries are responsible for the children in their care. Synonyms

[ U ] used as a combining form: skincare/healthcare/childcare take care of someone/something
B1 to protect someone or something and provide the things that that person or thing needs: Take good care of that girl of yours, Patrick - she's very special.
See more in care UK (also take/put into care)
Children who are in care or who have been taken/put into care are not living with their natural parents but instead with a national or local government organization or another family: Both children were taken into care when their parents died.
See more care in the community UK
a system in which people with mental illness or reduced mental ability are allowed to continue living in their own homes, with treatment and help, and are not kept in hospital: These people are supposed to be getting care in the community, but it's just not happening.

care noun
(ATTENTION)
B1 [ U ] serious attention, especially to the details of a situation or thing: She painted the window frames with great care so that no paint got onto the glass. You need to take a bit more care with your spelling. The roads are icy, so drive with care. Take care on these busy roads (= drive with attention so that you do not have an accident). [ + to infinitive ] Take care not to (= make certain that you do not) spill your coffee. [ + that ] Take care (= make certain) that you don't fall. The parcel had a label on it saying "Handle with care".
More examplesFewer examplesThey took care to be as tactful as possible.She took a lot of care over the wording of her speech.You need to take more care with your handwriting.Take care that you get there on time.Make sure he takes care if he insists on going up that ladder.

care verb [I]
(WORRY)
B1 to think that something is important and to feel interested in it or upset about it: She's never cared very much about her appearance. [ + question word ] I really don't care whether we go out or not. I don't care how much it costs, just buy it. "Was Lorna happy about the arrangements?" "I don't know and I don't care." Your parents are only doing this because they care about (= love) you. I couldn't care less C1 UK informal (also US I could care less)
used to emphasize rudely that you are not interested in or worried about something or someone: "Mike's really fed up about it." "I couldn't care less."
See more for all I care informal
used to say that you are not interested in or worried about what someone else is doing: You can go to the match with Paula, for all I care.
See more as if I care informal
used to say that you are not interested in or worried about something that has happened or that someone has said: He said he didn't approve of what I'd done, as if I cared.
See more who cares? B2 informal
used to emphasize rudely that you do not think something is important: "It looks as if we are going to lose." "Who cares?".
See more

COMMUNICATIONS
  ( abbreviation c/o) used in addresses when the person you are writing to is staying or working somewhere that is not the place where they usually live or work: You can send packages to me care of my hotel. Address your letters to Write On, c/o BBC, Broadcasting House, London.
take care of sth/sb
to look after or protect something or someone: Take care of your home: it's your largest asset. People are doing this job to put food on the table and take care of their children.
to deal with or be responsible for something: He suggested she could help run the firm and take care of the finances. I'll take care of all the travel arrangements.
